He hopes this will improve his economic situation even more.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING A COW THAT GAVE BIRTH TO A NEW CALF

loans.name: Cesar Antonio

texts.es:
Este cliente es ganadero de la zona de Cosiguina es casado y padre de 03 hijos los cuales a mantenido siempre con la crianza de ganado 
 El crédito lo solicita para ampliar su hato ganadero y por ende aumentar sus ingresos. En la foto se observa con uno de los novillos de desarrollo los cuales se encuentran en su finca de 5 manzanas donde efectúa la inversión
texts.en:
This client is a farmer in the Cosiguina zone. He is married and a father of 3 children, who he supports with what he grows on the farm. The credit he is soliciting is to grow his herd of livestock and in that way increase his earnings. In the photo he is shown with one of his steers that is developing on his farm, 5 blocks away from where he plans to implement his investment.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of livestock to produce milk

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna I. is from the village of Baybay, Liloy, zamboanga del Norte. She is 46 years old. Edna is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Edna owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Edna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Edna is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Edna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Noralyn

texts.en:
Norayln T. is from the village of Centro Napu, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Noralyn is married and has 3 children, 2 are in school and 1 is an infant. To make a living, Noralyn operates a small sari-sari store near at her house. She also enjoy to engaged in rice land redemption, for the preparation of her children future.  Not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Noralyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In May 2009, Noralyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.es:
Tomás es un padre de familia de 62 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y tres de sus seis hijos en el centro poblado menor Motupillo, del distrito de Pítipo, ubicado a una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se ha dedicado a la agricultura desde hace más de 30 años, el tiempo que lleva viviendo en la zona, usualmente siembra caña, maíz y yuca. Actualmente ha instalado hace 25 dias una hectárea de maíz en un terreno de cultivo cercano al lugar en donde vive. 

Este negocio no es la única fuente de ingreso con la que cuenta, ya que es consciente de que los ingresos que percibe por agricultura son temporales, por ello también se gana la vida en dos actividades ligadas a la agricultura: la apicultura y la crianza y venta de cuyes (mamiferos comestibles, oriundos de la región), posee algunas colmenas en su terreno de cultivo y cría sus animales en su vivienda para venderlos a los negociantes que usualmente visitan la zona en donde vive.

Tomás desea sembrar una hectárea adicional de maíz, además de brindarle un buen mantenimiento al cultivo que ya tiene para asegurarse una buena producción. Por ese motivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Tomás sueña con brindarle a su esposa y a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida. El ya es un cliente antigüo de Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado ser un cliente puntual y responsable al momento de asumir sus cuotas. En la imagen aparace junto a las jaulas donde cría sus cuyes.
texts.en:
Tomás is a father of a family, he is 62 years old and lives together with his wife and three of his six children in the center of a small town called Motupillo, in the district of Pítipo, located an hour and a half from the city of Chiclayo. He has worked in agriculture for more than thirty years, all fo which he has lived int he area, usually growing sugar cane, corn and yuca. Nowadays, twenty five days ago, he installed a hectare of corn in a plot of land close to where he lives. This business is not the only source of income on which he relies, he is conscious that the income that he receives from agriculture is seasonal, which is why he also makes a living in two activities outside of agriculture: beekeeping and the growing and sales of a type of guinea pigs, cuyes (edible mammals, native to the region). He possess some beehives on his plot of land, and cares for his animals in order to sell them to businessmen who usual visit the area where he lives. Tomás wants to grow an additional hectare of corn, and furthermore to provide a good mantience of the crop that he already has in order to assure a good production. For this reason he has seen the need to ask Edpyme Alternativa, an affiliate of Kiva, for a loan of 1500 Soles to help him achieve his objective. Tomás dreams to provide his wife and his children a better quality of life. He is an old client of Nuestra Institución and has demonstrated that he is a punctual and responsible client the moment he takes on his loans. In the photo he is shown by the cages where he grows his guinea pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Lois Parshley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Costs of growing and maintaining a crop of corn.

loans.name: Eloisa

texts.en:
Eloisa is a married mother of four children. Her husband is a construction worker (laborer) in the community, while she manager her own buy-and-sell business to provide additional income for the family. Eloisa is a hard working entrepreneur who has been in business for almost three years.

Eloisa would like to receive a loan as working capital for her business to buy raw materials like aluminum steel for windows and doors, and a glass. A proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) (a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines) since 2006, Eloisa has been a dedicated member demonstrating regular attendance to weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans.

Her long-term goal that soon is to have an expanded business. Also, she hopes the profits from her business will fund the continued education for all four children. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Eloisa is determined to achieve business success to build more long-term financial security for herself and her family.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To fund raw materials like aluminum steel for windows and doors, and a glass.

loans.name: Laura Marcela

texts.es:
Laura Marcela F. y su esposo están preocupados por el bienestar de su familia, en este momento están pasando por un momento tan difícil. La mama del señor se encuentra enferma y los medicamentos que le están pidiendo están muy caros. 
Laura esta preocupada por la salud de su suegra y la estabilidad de su esposo es por ello que quiere un préstamo para poder comprar las medicinas para que la salud de su suegra mejore.
texts.en:
Laura Marcela F. and her husband are worried for the well-being of their family, and at this point they are going through a difficult time. Her husband's mother is sick and the medication that she needs are very expensive. Laura is worried about her mother-in-law's health and her husband's stability, and it is for these reasons that she requests a loan to be able to buy the medication to improve her mother-in-law's health.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of medication

loans.name: Rolom

texts.en:
Rolom is 48 years old and lives with her husband and their four children in Ovorhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Rolom operates two businesses: clothing manufacturing and meat selling. Rolom's personality and health are good, and her business experience is improving. She plans to expand the business and increase her profits in the future. She has been operating the meat selling business with her husband at the rental counter of the Zanabazar market since 1998. Presently, her working capital is 1,500,000 tugrugs (~ 1055 USD), her average monthly sales revenue is 2,600,000 tugrugs (~ 1829 USD), and her monthly profit is 370,000 tugrugs (~ 260 USD).

Previously, Rolom had been operating a clothing manufacturing business, which she still runs in her spare time. She operates this business with her daughter, and they produce "deel" (Mongolian traditional clothing), coats, bags, and more. Rolom is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~ 1400 USD ) loan to purchase a large amount of silk and material in order to produce and sell Mongolian traditional clothing during the upcoming Mongolian Lunar New Year celebration. Rolom is a decent, very hardworking, precise and optimistic person. She would like to create a secure financial future in order to continue to pay for her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of silk and material

loans.name: Mrs. Lon Pach Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has seventeen people who live in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. Mrs. Lon P. is a village bank president who has been selected by all the members.  They will each use their loan for different purposes.  All the members are shown in the photo, although some are obscured. 

Mrs. Lon P. is a Khmer noodle seller and also owns a general store in the local village.  She is a mother of four children, two of whom are attending the local public school, a third is employed in garment factory, and the last is too small to work or study. 

Her husband, Mr. Eng Sou, is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice for supporting the family.  In the rice field, they have some problems because their field is infertile soil, but they do not have money to improve it. Thus, in order to increase rice production, Mrs. Lon P. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Fabiana

texts.en:
Fabiana T. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 67 years old and is widowed. Fabiana owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as candies, biscuits, salt, sugar, shampoo, soap, toothpaste and other items. She also sells e-load for Smart Communications phones in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Fabiana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Fabiana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her third from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mrs. Yat C. (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Sivan Pin, have been married since 2002 and just have a one-year-old daughter. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Yat has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old. She also taught her husband to become a silk weaver. They sell their finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in a Phnom Penh market. 

Yat had a previous Kiva loan which she fully repaid.  She now is requesting another loan of $50 to buy silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for continuing her weaving business.

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita M. is from the village of Poblacion, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years old. Clarita is single and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Clarita owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as candies, sugar, salt, candies, Milo (cocoa mixture), milk sachets, shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Clarita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Clarita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used additional capital for her business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Clarita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Angelo

texts.en:
Angelo P. is from the village of Villa Sudiacal Liloy. He is 43 years old. Angelo is married and has 2 school-aged children. He owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. Angelo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $130 US) for these activities.

In 2009, Angelo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Angelo is requesting a new loan, which will be his third, of 20,000 PHP. He will use it to expand the business.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve and expand the business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Expanding the business

loans.name: Chi

texts.en:
Chi T., age 31, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She has a business selling vegetables and buys rice in bulk for resale, earning an income of $1 US per day. 

Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $5 US per day. By doing so, he is able to cover the family's expenses, especially the children’s education. He has been in this job since 2004. 

T. is requesting a loan of $300 US to purchase more rice in bulk for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk for resale

loans.name: Emerita

texts.en:
Emerita C. is from the village of Malinao, Gingoog city. She is 57 years old. Emerita is widowed and has 7 adult children.  She owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling food & daily use products in the local community. Emerita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. 

In 2003, Emerita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emerita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. This new loan will be the 8th she has taken out from HSPFI.  Emerita is requesting 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Richel

texts.en:
Richel A. is from the village of Estrella, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old. Richel is married. To make a living, Richel works in someone else's business venture, operating a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling health & medicinal products in the local community. Richel has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Richel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Richel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Richel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Richel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Kweyamba Women's Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Proscovia in the small photo at the top left also appears in the big photo and she is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a determined and hard working lady with a business of selling soft drinks from Namawojolo market. Her business is mostly affected by seasonal changes, especially the rainy seasons where the sales fall tremendously. 

She is able to make 105,000 Ugandan shillings (about $52 US) as profits a week due to the experience of over 12 years that she has in the business. However, she needs to buy a motorcycle that she will use to bring in an extra income by hiring someone to ride it.  She is also continuing to educate her children and look after her parents. She is a mother of 5 children and also takes care of one dependent. She needs a loan to be able to stock more soft drinks as well as pay complete school fees for her children.

loans.use: Soft drinks for resale; children's school fees

loans.name: Togoosuren

texts.en:
Togoosuren is 41 years old and lives with her husband and their two children in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, in a rented plot of land with a yard. Togoosuren pays 20,000 tugrugs (about $14 US) per month in rent. She and her family have been living in their current home for five years. 

Togoosuren started her scarf weaving and cashmere/camel wool/yak hair sweater business at her home in 2004.  Originally, she would weave by hand, but she has been using two weaving machines for the business recently. Because of her hard work and determination, she was able to pay for her children's education fees and was able to support her two daughters in homes of their own.  

Generally, she spends the profits from her business on her household and her children's educational fees.  Togoosuren has many orders from her customers because she produces high quality and fashionable products.  She is a decent, open, helpful and very hardworking person. She says, “I'm working hard to give a high quality education to my two children, and to help my children become good people with good morals.” She is requesting an 800,000 tugrug loan.

loans.use: To purchase more wool

loans.name: Metchelie

texts.en:
Metchelie D. P. is from the village of Tabuan, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 26 years old. Metchelie is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Metchelie owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services in the local community. Metchelie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Metchelie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Metchelie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Metchelie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Metchelie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Norn

texts.en:
Mr. Norn C. is a villager who lives in Rung village, Takeo province. He and his wife are farmers who own a 2 hectare field to cultivate rice. This couple has four children, three of whom are students in the local school while the other one is too young to study or work.

Aside from farming, Mr. Norn C. is also a farm laborer and can earn a small income to support his family.  Mr. Norn C. needs 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy a motorbike for transportation to his work place.  His wife is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun K., age 54, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has eight children.

K. has a business selling groceries in her village, earning an income of US$5 per day and her husband is a farmer, earning an income of US$3 per day. With this income, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. She has been with this job since 2001.

K. is requesting a loan of US$700 to purchase more groceries to stock her store. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock her store

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena L. is from the village of Malinao, Gingoog City. She is 31 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Elena owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2003, Elena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elena is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 9th from HSPFI. She chose to remain at the 7,000 pesos level for her 9th loan. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Hermocilia

texts.en:
Hermocilia A. is from the village of Minlasag, Sibutad, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 62 years old, is married, and has seven adult children.

Hermocilia is engaged in farming and tills her own ricefield. She has been engaged in her business for twenty-five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month or 9,000 per harvest.

In 2007, Hermocilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. 

Hermocilia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchased fertilizer and other things/materials needed for her existing agricultural business. This loan will be her 5th losn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living condition of the borrower's family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To restock her business with fresh produce

loans.name: Khim

texts.en:
Mrs. Khim K. is 43 years old and is a villager who lives in Chrak Chi Koam village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Bav Keam, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. Mrs. Khim K. is also rice seller who is able to earn a small income to support her family.

Since her business is going well, Mrs. Khim K. wants to expand it. Thus she decided to ask for a loan from AMK to buy more rice to sell to continue enlarging her business.

Mrs. Khim K. is the mother of eight children, three of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory while the other five are students in the public school and also support their parents' business. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more rice to sell

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza C. is from the village of Malinao , Gingoog City. She is 23 years old. Analiza is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Analiza owns & operates a motorcycle services business (know as habal habal) which her husband manages in the local community members. Analiza has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Analiza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analiza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Analiza is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Analiza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 52-years-old, married with five children, and lives in the province of Rizal with her husband, Saturmino.   Her husband has been engaged in the fishing business for almost thirty years to support the family.  

To supply additional income for her family, Gloria would like to receive a new loan of 20,000PHP to expand the family’s fishing business.  With the loan, she will purchase raw materials including fish cages and nets.  With additional equipment, Gloria believes their fish inventory will increase thus generating higher income and profits from the business.
 
A dedicated member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2004, Gloria grateful for access to capital to support her entrepreneurial dreams.  Gloria has achieved strong performance with regular attendance to group meetings and steady repayments.   With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Gloria is hopeful the family business will continue to flourish, deliver steady income, and support improvements in her family’s quality of life.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials including fish cages and nets.

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhom C. is 40 years old and a villager who lives in Prech village in Takeo province. She is a grocery seller who owns a small store. Her husband, Mr. Hun Men, is a security guard for a private company where he makes a small salary to support his family living. Her husband has to travel far for work. Thus, Mrs. Sokhom C. now is requesting 1,500,000 Riel from AMK to purchase a motorbike to support her husband transportation. This couple has two children who all are students in the local school. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Basooka Kwavula Group, Mukono

texts.en: N. Harriet at the top left also appears in the group photo and she is the leader of her group in Mukono. She is 40 years old and married with 3 children as she takes care of her parents. She deals in the selling of fresh fish from Kame market in Mukono and the biggest challenge she has is finding the ice to preserve her fish. She has been in the business for 7 years and she is able to make some profits that enable her take good care of her family and boosting her business. Harriet is good at handling her customers and her goal is to expand her business further and have different stalls from which to transact her business. She needs a loan to help her with a bulk purchase of fish from the fishermen on the lakes.

loans.use: Purchasing fish in bulk.

loans.name: Nhean

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhean S. (pictured here), 57, is widow. She lives with her sister and elderly mother on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Nhean has been selling vegetable (tomato and cucumber) since she was 18 years old. She buys it from her village for resale in front of a garment factory. She is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase vegetable under contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable under contract for resale.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene D. is from the village of   Malinao ,  Gingoog City. She is 68 years old. Irene is widowed and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Irene owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Irene has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities. Irene chose to have 7000 thousand worth of loan for her 8th cycle loan.

In 2003, Irene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Irene is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Irene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Mr. Buntheng Sem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has fifteen people who live in Trapeang Roka village in Takeo province. Mr. Buntheng S. is a village bank president who has been selected by all the members they will use a loan in different purpose. He owns a harvest machine to rent to farmers and his wife, Mrs. Chanra K., is a farmer who owns 2-hectare of land to cultivate rice for supporting her family. In the rice field, they have some problems because their field is far from the irrigation system. Thus, in order to improve productive rice, Mr. Buntheng S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fuel. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in local public school, and the others are too small to work or study. 

On the day of the loan disbursement Mr. Buntheng S. was busy working in the field. Instead, his wife, Mrs. Chanra K., received the loan for him. The photo above is of Mr. Buntheng S.'s wife.

loans.use: To buy fuel

loans.name: Khoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Khoeurn U. is 48 years old and she lives in Angk Sangkae village in Takeo province.  She and her husband, Mr. Thou Nop, are farmers who own 1.5 hectare to cultivate rice. Mrs. Khoeurn U. now is requesting 1,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline to support her farming. With this loan they hope that they would be able to help her to increase the family income from their farmer. This couple has five children, three of whom are workers in a restaurant while two other are students in the local school. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline

loans.name: Nakisunga Development Group, Mukono

texts.en: S. Cate at the top left also appears in the group photo and she is the leader of her group in Mukono. She is 43 years old and married with 7 children as she takes care of 1 orphan, yet all the children are in school. Cate is a friendly lady with a salon business in Nakisunga that has been in existence for 17 years and she is able to make 35,000/= as profits weekly although she is faced with a challenge of the defaulters that usually affect her cash flow. She has a goal of building a residential house of her own for rent as well as expanding her business and being able to get her children’s school dues on time and being able to feed them continuously. Cate needs a loan to be able to restock her salon with more goods like braids, weaves, hair chemicals, hair pieces and so on.

loans.use: Restocking her salon with more goods like braids, weaves, hair chemicals, hair pieces and others.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora P. is from the village of  Gingoog City. She is 46 years old. Nora is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Nora owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of food products like viands and rice in the local community. Nora has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities. She chose to remain at 5000 thousand pesos worth of loan in her 2nd cycle.

In 2009, Nora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Nora is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mikisa Development Group, Mukono

texts.en: M. Jessie at the top left is the leader of her lending group and also appears in the group photo. She is a widow with 3 children, one of them a professor, and she takes care of her siblings. Jessie has had a retail shop in Kikooza for 8 years and although her shop has inadequate capital, she is able to make 100,000/= as profits every week. She is where she is with her shop because she has a good selection of what she sells hence attracting more customers each day. She hopes to expand her shop to be able to sell more as well as maintaining her good standard of living. She is a hard-working lady and hopes to expand her shop by buying more general merchandise for her shop with the loan.

loans.use: Restocking her shop with general merchandise.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 40 years old and married with four children.  Three of her children are in high school and one is attending elementary school.  Flora lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines.  Her husband works long hours as a fisherman to support the family.  To supply additional income, Flora wants to expand the family fishing business through additional working capital. 

Flora would like to receive a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase fish nets, rope, and additional raw materials.  With additional equipment, Flora believes that her fish supply will increase, providing higher revenue and profits for the family’s retail business.

A member of ASHI since 2009, Flora has achieved strong performance with regular attendance at group meetings and steady repayments.  Flora is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.  With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that their expanded business will continue to flourish to improve the family’s quality of life and fund all of her children’s college education.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the most poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase fish nets, rope, and additional raw materials

To make a living, Teresa owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Teresa has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Teresa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Teresa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Mrs. Uok Mom Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has seventeen people who live in Trapeang Angk village in Takeo province. Mrs. Uok M. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members; they will use their loans for different purposes. She is a weaver in the local village. She is a widow who lives with five dependents in her household. However hard she works, she can only earn a little income. Thus, in order to improve family living conditions, Mrs. Uok M. decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk for weaving. All the members of the group are shown in the picture, but some of them are blocked.

loans.name: Magezi Bugaga Group, Mukono

texts.en:
At the top left of the group photo is N. Jane. She is 50 years old and the leader of her lending group in Mukono. Jane is a hard-working lady with a retail shop business in Kisega that has been in existence for 20 years, and she is happy that she is able to make weekly profits amounting to 100,000/=. She is married with 7 children as she also takes care of  orphans. In order to continue taking good care of her family in every way, she hopes to expand her business by constructing her own business premises so that she can stop renting.  This will also enable her to provide school fees for all her dependents. 

Jane needs a loan to be able to restock her shop with more goods as well as to pay school fees for her children. She says that all in all, her loans help to boost her capital base. (At the back left is the Accountant for the branch, hence not part of the group.)

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods and completing school fees for her children

loans.name: Savet

texts.en:
Mrs. Savet K. (in the photo), 57, and her husband, Mr. Sam-ol Chab, 61, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1971 and have 8 children: 2 sons and 6 daughters. Four of them are married and live in separate homes, and two are garment factory workers. The other two are in school. One weaves silk at home and another is a construction worker. 

Savet has been a silk weaver since she was 22 years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband also works. She is requesting a loan of US$ 800 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

He is happy that he is able to take good care of his family and in future, he needs to buy another 'boda boda' so that he can continue to pay his children’s school fees since the higher they go, the more expensive it becomes. He needs a loan to be able to repair his motorcycle engine so that he can use it to make more money.

texts.en:
K. Grace, whose photo appears at the top left, is the leader of the lending group (she also appears in the group photo). She is 30 years old and a very hard working married lady with 5 children between 3 and 15 years of age.  All the children are in school.

She has a business selling old clothing from Runyerere trading centre from which she is able to make 17,500 Ugandan Shillings as profit every week. She says that her biggest expense is her children’s school fees.  She hopes to expand her business further by having a bigger stock of clothing so that she could save more. She knows how to handle her customers well and she needs a loan to be able to buy more used clothing for resale so that her business expands.

loans.use: Buying more clothing for resale.

loans.name: Rwenyerere Bakyara Tukwatanise Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
T. Dominic is a happy man just like he appears in the top left small photo and at the far left of the group photo. He is a hard working man and married with 5 children aged 12, 10, 6, 4 & 2 years old.  He has been involved in the business of selling timber from Buzaniro trading centre for 5 years from which he is able to make 240,000 Ugandan Shillings as profit monthly.

Dominic says that he started so small 5 years ago and his hard work and continued persistence have enabled him to grow, although some clients default thereby affecting his business cash flow. He hopes to have a bigger workshop in future that will make it possible to educate all his children once they join higher levels of education.

Dominic needs a loan that will help him facilitate his day to day workshop business like paying workers and buying more timber, and this will improve his working capital.

loans.use: Buying more timber for resale.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

She ensures that her school maintains good performance and her goal is to ensure that her school’s standard grows continuously. She is 30 years old and divorced with two children aged 10 and 9 years. They are both in primary school. She also takes care of her sister. Doreen is a hard working lady who has been selling old/used clothes from Kiruruma trading centre for five years. Her profits amount to 50,000/= a week. She ensures that her goods are of good quality and she uses her good customer care skills. She hopes to expand her business with more quality stock so that she can pay for her children’s education since she is a single mother. She needs a loan to be able to buy other clothes for resale.

loans.name: Vat

texts.en: Vat S., age 43, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has one child. She raises pigs at home, earning an income of US $5 per day. Her husband grows sugar cane for sale, earning the same amount of income. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially those for the children’s education. Godfrey has been selling spare parts from Lugazi for 10 years and although he is able to make 150,000/= profit weekly, he is affected by the transport costs to Kampala where he buys his stock. This why loans help him to buy in bulk. Therefore he does not have to move all the time. He hopes to continue working hard so that he can offer a good education to his children and he believes this will be possible if he has a steady supply of goods in his shop. Godfrey needs a loan to be able to buy more spare parts for resale.

Sok S., age 53, is widowed and lives with her two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Since 2008 she has run a business selling crushed ice with sweet syrup in her village, earning an income of $2.5 USD per day. One of her children helps her in this business. By doing so, S. is able to cover her family expenses, especially her children’s education.
S. is requesting a loan of $500 USD to purchase a machine to crush ice to expand her current business. This is her first loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a machine to crush ice

loans.name: Ssanganzira Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
B. Eva (shown inset top left as well as in the main photograph) is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 41 years old, married, and has three children aged 10, 13 and 16.
She has had a retail shop business in Kawomya trading centre for seven years and her biggest challenge is the scarcity of capital. This is where a loan comes in as it enables her to have more and better quality stock from which she makes more profit. Eva is a very determined woman, and in the future she hopes to transform her shop into a wholesale shop so that she can better take care of her family and provide for the children’s education. She is requesting a loan to buy more sugar, salt, soap and other general merchandise for her store.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, salt, soap and other general merchandise

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic S. is 20 years old and has three children between one and three years old. She lives on an island with more than 60 other families. Marivic owns a small boat which her husband uses for catching fish. The income she gets from her fishing business helps her a lot, especially in buying food and clothes and meeting other basic needs.
Marivic would like to apply for a loan of 10,000 PHP, which she will use to buy fishing materials such as baits and nets.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials such as baits and nets

loans.name: Kurbonali

texts.ru: Нелмуродов Курбонали проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст, 54 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, детский врачь. Один сын занимается починкой автомашины а другой военнослужиший. Сам Курбонали имеет высшее образование, но по специональности не работает. Он предоставляет услугу, такси. Перевозит людей с одного места на другое. В этой деятельности более 10 лет. Кредит берет для пакупки автомашины. Курбонали хочет продать свою старую автомашину и купить новую, чтобы предоставить безопасную услугу.
texts.en:
Kurbonali N. lives in Dushanbe. He is 54 years old; married with 3 children. His wife is a pediatrician. One of his sons is an auto mechanic, the other is in the military. Kurbonali has a higher education, but he does not work in his field. He is a taxi driver, offering the service of transporting people from one place to another. He has been in this business for over 10 years. He is requesting the loan to purchase a car. Kurbonali wants to sell his old car and buy a new one, in order to make his service safer.

Translated from Russian by Anna Melyakova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying a car

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en:
Mrs. Marisa A. is 38 years old, married, and has two children. She lives in Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur. Her husband is a tricycle driver and he supports their basic daily needs. Marisa sells her vegetables at the public market in Tambulig. From her vegetable-vending business she approximately earns 4,000 PHP a month.
Marisa successfully repaid her previous loan of 4,000 PHP from Kiva partner, PMPC. The purpose of that loan was to buy other kinds of vegetables to sell. As of now, she has a new loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC and that loan is intended for her business only. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her vegetable-vending business

loans.name: Nkobazambogo Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
K. Daudi (shown inset top left as well as in the main photograph) is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a determined and hardworking married man with three children aged four, six and nine years old. He also takes care of his parents.
Daudi has had a grocery business in Ngogwe for two years, from which he makes 120,000 UGX as weekly profit. Before he had this business, he was just a farmer. With the help of a loan, Daudi has learned to take his produce to the market. He also buys from other farmers when his stock is not sufficient. He ensures that his produce is of good quality and mostly deals in fruit and vegetables. He hopes to expand his customer base depending on what he has for sale.
For the future, Daudi has a plan of buying a plot of land in the trading center in the hope that he can make it a commercial success once he has the funds to do so. He is requesting a loan to buy more produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more produce for his grocery business

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Mrs. Erlinda P. is 53 years old, married, and has five children. She is from Molave, Zamboanga del Sur. Her husband is a retired salesman and supports their basic daily needs. Erlinda owns a sari-sari (general) store and, at the same time, is a SmartLoad retailer. She has managed her store for almost ten years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP per month.
Erlinda joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid her previous loan of 13,000 PHP taken from PMPC. The purpose of that loan was to expand her sari-sari store. As of now, she has a new loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC, which is to be used as additional capital to buy products to sell. This will be her fifth loan from PMPC.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Nga's Group

texts.en:
Nga N. T. is 62 years old. ( id: 010103040018). She lives in Dong Dau village, Duc Tu, Dong Anh. She has 3 children. They are married and have income. She lives with her older son. Ms Nga is a farmer. Every day she takes care of her grandson and raises chicken at home. She has a monthly income of about 2.000.000 VND.

She has joined SEDA's activities to borrow money for raising chickens. At the present time, she would like to take out a loan of 5.014.000 VND( or about 265 USD) for this round to invest in her poultry, hoping that it will make a profit so that her family can afford to buy more furniture.

Ms. Nga is leading a group consisting of 4 other members: 

Toan N. V. is 31 years old. ( id: 010103040013). He wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND (or about 265 USD) to invest in his shop making glass windows.
 
Thanh P. T. is 29 years old. ( id:010103040014). He wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND (or about 265 USD) to invest in his bicycle repair shop (to buy bicycle parts). 

Phuong N. T. is 29 years old. ( id:010103040033). She breeds poultry. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND (or about 265 USD) to buy feed for her chickens.

Mai T. N. is 43 years old. ( id:010103040023). She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND (or about 265 USD) to breed pigs and raise poultry.

loans.use: to invest in her poultry raising

loans.name: Sharon's Group

texts.en:
Sharon E. owns a sari-sari (general) store. She sells soap, shampoo, rice, sardines and other canned goods, to generate an income to meet her needs. Sharon says: "I decided to set up a sari-sari store because I can earn enough money in this business. In 2008, I joined the CEVI microcredit program because I have a dream of constructing our own house". 
Sharon is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her store.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora C. is from the village of Baybay Disud, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 34 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Flora owns and operates a business venture selling food daily in the local community. Flora has been engaged in her business for ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Flora joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional raw products to sell. Flora is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her second loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as additional capital

location.town: Baybay Disud, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha Y. is 46 years old and has seven children, the eldest of whom is 23 years old. She invested her savings into a sari-sari (general) store business, and she also manages an eatery business. She decided to have multiple businesses because she wanted to earn more money for her family.
Editha is a client of Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP, which she will use to buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari and eatery businesses.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en: Thelma M. is from the village of Carangan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 55 years old, is married, and has one adult child. Thelma owns and operates a grocery store. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Thelma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional grocery stock. This will be her first loan from PMPC. Thelma plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional groceries for her store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
Jane B. is from the village of Alimannao, Penablanca, Cagayan. She is 28 years old. Jane is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jane is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Jane works in a family member's business venture in the food sector making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Jane has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,800 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Jane is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the third loan taken out by Jane from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly made up of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria A. owns a sari-sari (general) store, selling a variety of goods. Her wish is to have a stable business so that she will be able to support the needs of her family.

In 2007, Maria joined Community Economic Ventures Inc. She was glad about it because she now has ready access to additional capital for her business.

Now, Maria wants to apply for a loan of Php 15,000. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her store.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy S., 22 years old, is a young operator of a boat in Talibon, Bohol. She provides transportation in the city, especially to people who wish to go to the island. She has one child who is seven years old.

Now it will be her third loan from CEVI. The loan of Php 10,000, which she hopes to receive, will go far in paying the repair bill for her boat.

loans.use: To repair her pumpboat

loans.name: Dosumbetova Seyil`s Group

texts.en: Seyil is 72 years old and is a native of Uzgen city, which is one of the ancient cities of Central Asia. Officially she is a pensioner but she is still very active. She is married with twelve children! Wow! It is a very big number even for Central Asia. Her husband is also a pensioner. All her children are grown and most of them live separately from their parents. Seyil has a family business: they raise rice, corn and sunflowers. She has been in this business since 2001. Also they keep some cattle and sell milk and milk products. This loan will be used to buy building materials (cement) to repair their house. Aytolkun is 49 and she is a younger sister of Seyil. She is 49 years old and is married. She is raising two children: a 15-year-old son and a 9-year-old daughter, both pupils. Her husband is a farmer and they have a small livestock business. With this loan she hopes to buy a few lambs to fatten. Asilkan is 68. She is also a pensioner and married and has raised nine children. Due to her hard work, all her children live separately and happily, and they are very thankful to their mother. With her husband she fattens cattle. This loan will be used to buy milk cows, so that she will be able to produce more milk. S. Apakan is married with three children. She is 68 years old and receives a pension of about USD 30. She sells milk and milk products in her village. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy cement to repair her house

loans.name: Rosela

texts.en: Rosela P. is from the village of Purok Pag-asa, Salawagan, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Rosela owns and operates a specialized retail business, selling beauty products like whitening lotion, perfume and other items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Rosela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rosela is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Parda

texts.ru: Одинаев Парда проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 38 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Родители и брат живут вместе с ними. Сам Парда занимается торгвлей. У него магазин, где он продает корма животных. В этой деятельности более 4 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота. На полученный доход хочет расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Parda O. lives in the Yavan region. He is 38 years old; married with 2 children. His wife is a housewife. His parents and brother live with him. Parda is in the sales business. He owns a store, in which he sells fodder. He has been in this business for over 4 years. He is requesting the loan to increase the volume of sales. With the profits he wants to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Melyakova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase volume of trade

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen C. is from the village of Purok Pag-asa, Quezon Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Aileen is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Aileen owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ready-to-wear (RTW) clothing in the local community. Aileen has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Aileen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aileen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Aileen is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Aileen's second loan taken from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Modesto

texts.en:
Modesto A., 39, lives on an island at Talibon Bohol. He has seven children. His eldest child is 17 years old. He says that fishing is his only source of livelihood. Aside from fish, he is also engaged in seaweeds farming. These two occupations have helped Modesto pay their daily household expenses. 

He would like to apply a loan of 8,000 PHP to buy fishing boats and a compressor.

loans.use: To buy compressor machine and fishing boat

loans.name: Davlatmand

texts.ru: Нодиров Давлатманд проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 26 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Жена, домохозяйка. Родители живут вместе с ними. Давлатманд зарабатывает путем разведения крупно- рогатого скота. Имеет не большой коровник. Покупает молодых бычков, откармливает и продает на рынке. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 10 лет. Это помогает обеспечивать его семью. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Davlatmand N. lives in the Yavan district. He is 26 years old, married and has one child. His wife is a homemaker. The parents live together with them. Davlatmand earns a living by breeding cattle and has a small cow barn. He buys young bulls, feeds them up and sells them at the market. He has been involved in this type of business for 10 years. This business helps him provide for his family. Davlatmand is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima R. is from the village of Bolinao. She is 29 years old. Fatima is the group leader of a 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Fatima R.'s Group'.

Fatima is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Fatima owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Fatima has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2008, Fatima joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fatima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Fatima is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Fatima from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly made up of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita L., 49, is from the village of PII, Kiburiao, Quezon Bukidnon. Teresita is a widowed mother of seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Teresita's fourth loan taken from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sofia Nakaggwe ‘S Group

texts.en:
Sofia is 35 years of age.  She is married with five children aged between 3 and 16 years. All her children go to school. The family owns a four-room house where she lives with eight other people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no running water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include: utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and food. 

Sofia operates a retail shop selling all kinds of merchandise in Ndeeba. She serves an average of 30 customers a day, and has had this business for over twenty years.  Sofia buys her merchandise from shops in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala.  Thus she incurs transport costs to go to Kikuubo and to bring her goods back. Her main business challenges are defaulters, the rainy season (because she works from a muddy place) and the ever-increasing prices of merchandise.

Sofia has been with MCDT for over nine years.  She is requesting her twentieth loan with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerrycans of cooking oil. She hopes to grow her business and start selling at wholesale prices only. 
.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Maria Charito's Group

texts.en:
Maria Charito A. is from the village of Brgy. Lantap, Bagabag, Neuva Vizcaya. She is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Maria Charito is 46 years old, married and she has 3 school-aged children. To make a living Maria Charito sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Maria Charito has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Maria Charito joined ASKI to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Charito successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which she used to purchase additional products to sell.

Maria Charito is requesting her fourth loan from ASKI, for 12000 PHP, which she will use to purchase new items to expand her product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business.

About ASKI

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Note

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma M. is from the village of Menongan, Quezon Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Wilma is widowed and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Wilma owns and operates a variety store. The store sells food and other daily-used products in the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Wilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her store's product offering. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Wilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
