loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena I. is 25 years old and has four children; the oldest is seven years old.  Lorena sells seashells and fish. She also has a seaweed farm and sells seaweed to a regular buyer in Talibon. The income she gains from her business helps to support her family.

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy seaweed seedlings and seashells.

loans.use: To buy seaweed seedlings and seashells

loans.name: Kulakulana Group, Mukono

texts.en: Mary N. is the chairperson of her group in Katosi. She runs a tailoring business from her home. She makes and mends clothes and sells a few new clothing items from a stall. She is grateful for her loans because they have enabled her to transform her business. Now she no longer has difficulty taking care of her family, since her business is profitable. Mary needs a loan to be able to buy more clothing materials and supplies for her business, and to partly pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: Buying clothing materials and supplies for her business.

loans.name: Hadjah Nankya's Group

texts.en:
Hadjah is 42 years of age.  She is married with six children aged between 3 and 18 years. All her children go to school. The family owns a four-room house where she lives with ten people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include: utility bills, school fees for children, medication and food. 

Hadjah owns a stall in the Ndeeba market selling bananas. Hadjah buys her bananas nearby, so she doesn’t incur any transport costs.  She serves an average of 30 customers a day. She has run this business for over twenty-five years.  Her main business challenges are: defaulters, the rainy season (because she works from a muddy place) and the ever-increasing price of bananas.  She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over nine years. She is requesting her twentieth loan working with the same group. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She aspires to grow her business and start buying directly from farmers. 
.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Florely's Group

texts.en:
Florely Q. is from the village of Villa Corazon, Mallig, Isabela. She is 32 years old. Florely is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Florely Q.'s group.

Florely is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Florely owns & operates a business venture into making & selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Florely has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Florely joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Florely is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Florely from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en: Armando P. is from the village of Menongan, Quezon, Bukidnon. He is 36 years old. Armando is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Armando owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food, daily-use products and soft drinks in the local community. loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 38 years of age, married with six children aged between 3 and 18 years, all attending school. The family owns and resides in a four-roomed house where she stays with five people, the rest of the children residing in the village with her parents. Florence takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home and has three meals a day. Florence's greatest monthly expenses include the utility bills, school fees for the children, medication, and food for the family.

For over ten years Florence has owned a mini-bakery retailing chapatti from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala, and so incurs transport costs to and from shopping and receives an average of 40 customers a day. Her main challenges are defaulters, the rainy season because she works from a muddy place, and ever-increasing prices for baking flour and cooking oil.

She has been with MCDT for over seven years and will now be servicing her sixteenth loan, working all this time with the same group mates. Florence wants to use this loan to buy more cartons of baking flour and jerrycans of cooking oil. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and eventually hopes to start a big bakery .

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of  cooking oil and cartons of bakling flour

loans.name: Nasuuti Women's Group, Mukono

texts.en:
N. Juliet (shown fourth from the left) is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a smart, strong and hardworking woman who manages two businesses – she is a tailor and also has a retail shop. Both businesses are close to each other and this enables her to manage them well. Juliet makes 150,000 UGX weekly profits from both businesses. As a result, she is able to take good care of her family as well as develop her businesses.
Juliet hopes to open a tailoring school where she will teach people her trade as well as taking on some students as her employees. She believes that this will enable her to continue to pay school fees for her children and her dependants. She is requesting a loan to help restock her shop and buy materials for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop and buy more tailoring materials

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda B., from the village of Brgy. Quirino, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya, is 49 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns and operates a general store that sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over four years, earning approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP that was used to purchase additional products to sell, Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase new items to expand the store's product offerings. This loan will be her second from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the store to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Enecita

texts.en:
Enecita B. is from the village of P-10, Puerta, Lurugan, Valencia City. She is 51 years old, separated from her spouse, and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Enecita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Enecita has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Enecita joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Enecita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is 38 years of age, married with two children aged 3 and 18 years, both of whom attend school. The family resides in a rented two-roomed house, and Edith takes care of additional family members. The family, which has access to electricity but no piped water at home, has three meals a day. Edith's greatest monthly expenses include the utility bills, school fees for her children, medication, and food for the family.

Edith has owned a banana stall at her home for over ten years; she buys bananas from Nalukolongo, one of the city's suburbs, and so incurs transport costs to and from shopping and receives an average of 20 customers a day. Her main challenges are defaulters, the rainy season because she works from a muddy place, and the ever-increasing prices of bananas She sells on a retail basis only . Edith has been with MCDT for over seven years and will now be servicing her sixteenth loan, working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches and clusters of bananas. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and hopes to soon start buying directly from farmers .

loans.use: To buy more bunches and clusters of bananas

loans.name: Rorn

texts.en: Mrs. Rorn N. is a 34-year-old married woman who lives in Lieb village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who has 1.50 hectares to grow rice. She has a problem because she does not have enough oxen to support her farm. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy an ox to support her farm. Her husband, Mr. Chantha Chea, is a teacher in the local school where he makes a small salary to support his family. He is also a palm juice collector. This couple has three children who all are students in the public school.

loans.use: To buy an ox

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea P., age 26, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has a child. She is a construction worker, earning approximately US $3 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family's expenses, especially those for her children’s education. She has been doing this business since 2009. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of US $7 per day. Their standard of living has improved since P.’s husband has been doing this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand his business. P. is requesting a loan of US $800 to buy more construction tools to expand his business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy construction tools

loans.name: Kathlene

texts.en:
Kathlene B. is from the village of Sugarland, Lumbo Valencia City. She is 23 years old. Kathlene is single and has two infant children. To make a living, Kathlene owns & operates a business providing manicure and pedicure services to local community members. Kathlene has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Kathlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Kathlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. Kathlene is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Kathlene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Khoeun S. is a 51-year-old married woman who lives in Cheav Bdei Khang Kaeut village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Moe Mil, are farmers who own a one-hectare field to grow rice. They face a problem because their field does not have enough water and is far from the irrigation system. Mrs. Khoeun S. decided to ask for a loan to dig a well to support her farming. Mrs. Khoeun S. is the mother of four children. One of the children is a laborer, two are students in the local school and the last one is a farmer who helps her parents on the farm. Her husband is on the left in the picture.

loans.use: To dig a well

loans.name: C1166 Intambwe Group

texts.en:
Thelesphore is 29 years old and is married with two children who are 7 and 2 years old. He and his family live in the Gicumbi district, a region of Byumba situated in the Northern Province of Rwanda. From here to Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda, it is a one-hour drive.

Thelesphore is the leader of this group, which consists of eight members; this group is called Intambwe. He and his team are known for a business selling foodstuffs, mainly Irish potatoes, potatoes, beans, rice, etc. The hours of the business are from 7 a.m. until late in the evening hours.

After five years of experience in the business of selling foodstuffs, Thelesphore and his team are requesting a Kiva loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. They want to add a large quantity of wheat, Irish potatoes, etc., in order to expand their business.

With this loan, Thelesphore and his team expect to earn more profits, which in turn will allow them to supply all the basic needs for their families. In addition, Telesphore and his team plan to save for the future reinvestment in their business.

loans.use: To buy additional foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Tongolo Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en: N. Zakiya is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 25 years old and very hard working with a business selling dried fish from her home area of Tongolo.  Being a single mother with two children in her care has taught her how to save, mostly for her children’s education and general upkeep, and she is grateful for this. She resorted to loans because they help her have enough stock for resale. She is able to make profits of over 100,000/= a week. She aims at expanding her business to ensure that she can earn more money and be able to educate her children to the highest level, and to achieve this, she resorted to smoking the fish herself for increased earnings. Zakiya needs a loan to help buy more fish for resale.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Virginia's Group

texts.en:
Virginia C. is from the village of Maligaya. She is 48 years old. Virginia is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. Virginia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia raises livestock, namely pigs, for fattening and sale. Virginia has been engaged in her business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virginia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Virginia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny S. is a 44-year-old married woman who lives in Andoung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.50-hectare (3.75-acre) field on which she cultivates rice.

In this farming, Mrs. Vanny S. faces a problem because she does not have enough money to support her field. Thus she decided to ask for 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy fertilizer and gasoline to support her farming.

Mrs. Vanny S. is the mother of five children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory while the other three are students in the local school. Her husband, Mr. Parng Sun, is a fish seller from which he makes a small income to support his family living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline for her farm

loans.name: Jowey

texts.en: Jowey P., 27, is a fisherman who owns a small boat. His income goes to help support his family. He is requesting a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy fishing trap and fish net.

loans.use: to buy fishing trap and fishing net

loans.name: Eron

texts.en: Eron is 48 years old and married with five children aged between 8 and 18 all of whom go to school. The family, which includes four additional family members she cares for, live in a three-room house. The house has electricity but no piped water. The family has three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and feeding the family. Eron owns a stall in Nakawa market selling second hand clothes. She buys these clothes from city markets in Owino so incurs transportation costs to and fro. She has been in this business for ten years and has an average of 10 customers a day. Her main challenges are defaulters, the rainy season because her work place is open, and the ever increasing cost of the second hand clothes she buys. She has been with MCDT for over seven years and is on her sixteenth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes and hopes to see her business expand.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. San M. is 56 years old and is a villager who lives in Andoung village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Song Miet, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. Aside from farming, Mr. Song Miet is also a pig breeder who is able to earn a small income to support his family living. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

In order to support her husband’s business, Mrs. San M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a pig to breed for piglets. This loan, she hopes, will increase their income and improve the family’s standard of living.

Mrs. San M. is the mother of three children, one of whom is a vegetable seller, another is a farmer who supports the parents’ farming, while the last one grows vegetables.

loans.use: To buy a pig to breed piglets
