loans.name: Tem

texts.en:
Tem N., age 46, is widowed and resides with her children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has three children.

N. raises pigs at home, earning an income of approximately US$2 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. She has been with this business since 1979.

N.’s sister (pictured here) sells food in her village, earning an income of US$3 per day. Her standard of living has been improved since she has operated her business, so N. wants to obtain a loan to expand it. She is requesting a loan of US$1,000 to expand her sister’s business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To expand her sister's food-selling business

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita B., 29 years old, is engaged in a fish-selling business. Her husband is a fisherman and they work together to be able to earn income and accommodate their needs.

Rosita wishes to buy new fishing nets and bait and also desires additional capitalization for her fish-selling business. She hopes to receive a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will really help to buy the fishing materials.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and bait and to add capital to her fish-selling business

loans.name: Kyadondo East Group, Mukono

texts.en: N. Nuluyat is a hardworking, friendly, and devoted woman. She is 41 years old and married with five children between the ages of 7 and 20. All of her children are still in school. Nuluyat has a retail shop that she has been running from Kirinya in Mukono for 10 years. She is able to make 50,000 UGX in weekly profits, and this helps her to expand her shop and to increase her capital base. She has a dream of expanding her shop further to ensure that she makes more profit to use for her children's education and general upkeep. Nuluyat needs a loan to be able to stock her retail shop with more goods in order to bring in more profit.

loans.use: To stock her retail shop with more goods

loans.name: Kimteung

texts.en: I. Kimteung, age 53, is married and lives wI. her husband in the Siem Reap province. She stays at home cooking and doing housework. Her husband, pictured here, is a farmer. He grows rice and vegetables to sell at the local market. On average, he is able to make about 4 USD per day. This couple also got support from one child who works as a garment factory worker in Phnom Penh city. I. Kimteung says that she spends about 25 USD on food, 15 USD on utilities, and 15 USD on transportation. Due to the high daily expense, Mrs. I. Kimteung would like to apply for a loan of 1000 USD from Kiva via CREDIT MFI in order to make two investments. She would like to invest 800 USD in raising fish and use the remaining 200 USD to purchase fertilizer for her husband. In the future, her husband wants to purchase another plot of land to expand their cultivation.

loans.use: To raise fish and purhcase fertilizer

loans.name: Sor

texts.en: Sor R., age 44, is married and resides with her children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has two children. She has a business of selling palm sugar, earning approximately US $3 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially those for the children’s education. She has been doing this business since 2008. Her husband is a skillful blacksmith, earning an income of US $2 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since R. started this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. R. is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase more palm sugar. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more palm sugar for resale

loans.name: Lum

texts.en: C. Lum, 40, is a widow and lives with three of her children in the Siem Reap province. Since 2006, she has been selling porridge and noodles to earn a living and is able to make about US $4 profit a day. Her daughter is a grocery seller. She earns US $2 a day. C. Lum is asking for a loan of US $300 to reinvest in her porridge and noodle businesses.

loans.use: To reinvest in her porridge and noodle businesses.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao N. is a 33-year-old married woman who lives in Preak Ta Ong Ti 2 village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Tha Thorn, are mango sellers who can earn a small income by selling their mangoes to support their family. Since their business is still going well, Mrs. Mao N. wants to expand it. She decided to ask for 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy more mangoes to enlarge her business. She hopes that the loan will increase the family income and improve the family's living conditions. Mrs. Mao N. is the mother of four children. Two of the children are students in the public school and two are too young to study or work. Her husband is on the left in the picture.

loans.use: To buy more mango

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gemalyn

texts.en:
Gemalyn D., 22 years old, has a fish-selling business. She has two children with the oldest being 2 years old. She desires to improve her livelihood so that she is able to save money to support the education of her children in the future. 

Gemalyn would like to ask for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy an additional pump boat to be used in fishing.

loans.use: To buy an additional pumpboat

loans.name: Chhourn

texts.en:
Chhourn S., age 57, is married and resides with her three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia.

S. has a business farming and raising animals, earning an income of approximately US$1 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. She has been with this business since 1985. Her husband is a skillful chef, earning an income of US$2 per day.

Their standard of living has been improved since S. is with this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. S. is requesting a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. This is her third loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to use for commuting

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony is a 35 year old, married man with one child. 

He has been operating a computer service business in Nairobi town for the past four years. As there are many people in the town center, he is in a very strategic position. His customers are mostly staff from the various offices in the town center. He offers typesetting and printing services. His wife Jane is also in business and they live in Cura which is on the outskirts of Nairobi town. 

Antony was introduced to KADET by a friend and this will be his first loan. He has no previous credit history with other microfinance institutions. He wants to use the money from this loan to buy another computer to improve the service he can offer to his customers.

Anthony hopes to open a computer training institute across Nairobi town. This will improve their living standard and he will be able to meet the needs of his customers.

loans.use: to buy another computer to improve his customer service

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie S. is from the village of Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 45 years old. Tessie is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Tessie owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Tessie has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Tessie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Tessie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Darwin

texts.en: Darwin V., 30, manages a small sari-sari (variety) store. He says that his business provides his family an average income of Php 2,000 a day. He has four children, the eldest is 11. He wants to grow his business more.  He would like to request a loan of Php 10,000 to buy additional merchandise to sell.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Dok

texts.en:
Dok K., 51, is married and resides with her children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has three children. 

She sells roast chickens and cooked rice and earns approximately US$3 per day. By doing this she is able to cover her family expenses, particularly her children’s education. She has been runing this business since 1993. Her husband is a skillful carpenter, earning an income of US$1.50 per day. 

Their standard of living has been improved since K. has been working in her business, so she wants a loan to expand. K. is requesting a loan of US$1,200 to purchase salt and watermelons to resell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: to buy salt and watermelon for resale

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn S. is from the village of Westfield, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 34 years old. Merlyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. Merlyn owns & operates a specialized retail store. Her main income comes from buying and selling used clothing, or ukay ukay, and some school supplies. Merlyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Merlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Merlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

location.town: Iponan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kwesitukira Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
N. Escalanda is a friendly old lady and the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a businesswoman who has managed a bar in her home area for so long. She mostly sells local brew as well as beers and some sodas in order to make the necessary profits from her business. She is also a farmer growing crops both for sale and for home consumption and this enables her to earn more.

All of Escalanda’s children are old and working and she helps to take care of her grandchildren, some of whom are orphans. This is the main reason why she gets loans in order to be able to earn funds for financing her dependents’ education.

Escalanda needs a loan to be able to buy more brew for resale, although some of it she makes herself.

loans.use: To buy more brew for resale and materials for making the brew herself

loans.name: Bernadeth

texts.en:
Bernadeth O. desires having a bigger store. She has four children that she hopes she could provide a good future for.

Bernadeth said that her business is going very well, but that she wants to prosper it more so that she could attend to the other needs of her children.

Bernadeth would like to apply for a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to sell.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita G. is from the village of Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 55 years old. Merlita is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Merlita owns and operates a business providing tailoring services to local community members. Merlita has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Merlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Merlita is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Merlita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread

loans.name: Meraluna

texts.en:
Meraluna B., 32, operates a fish retailing business. Her husband is a fisherman and they own a small boat. The couple also farm seaweed which helps supplement their income.

"My business is going so well now and it really helps my family buy food, clothing and other basic needs", she said. 

She is the mother of two children. Her eldest child is only 11 years old and is at high school.

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures to buy fishing materials

loans.use: To buy fishing materials

loans.name: Srun

texts.en:
Srun S.,  51, is married and lives with her children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has five children. 

She produces Cambodian traditional baskets and earns approximately US$11 gross per day. By doing this she is able to cover her family's expenses, particularly her children’s education. She has been with this business since 2000. Her husband grows mushrooms for sale, earning an income of US$7 per day. Their standard of living has improved since S. has been running her business. 

S. is requesting a loan of US$1,000 to expand her husband’s mushroom growing business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: to expand her husband's mushroom growing business

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma P. is from the village of Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 59 years old. Thelma is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Thelma owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling health and medicinal products in the local community. Thelma has been engaged in her business for more than seven years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Thelma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thelma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Thelma is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items in order to expand her product offering. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Thelma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her immediate family members. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items in order to expand her product offering

loans.name: Hafizahon Hasanova`s Group

texts.en: Sharipahon is the treasurer of this group. She is 40 and is the mother of a 7 year old daughter. This is her second loan from MBF. Her husband is an accountant in the local bus station. Sharipahon has her own trade outlet in the village center. She has been in this business for more than 10 years. At first she traded from her house but then she saved enough money and bought an outlet. Now her turnover is about USD 1250. This loan will be used to buy additional women's clothes for her business. Sharipahon and her husband are saving money to buy a car. Hafizahon, 32, is married with 2 children. Her husband is a cook in a local cafe. After she gave birth to her second child, her friends recommended that she open a food outlet. She currently has a big market. She works there herself. The average income per month is about USD 200. This loan will enable her to increase the turnover. Gulbarchyn is the youngest member of this group. She is not married yet. She lives with her parents. They have a family business: livestock breeding and milk production. Every member of her family has their own responsibilities: her father buys and sells cattle, Gulbarchyn and her brother feed them and her mother sells milk. They have 4 cows and 4 sheep. This loan will be used to buy 5 sheep. In early spring the animals will be sent to pasture land. Muminjan, 35, is married with 2 children. He is an attorney. His wife has her own trade outlet selling socks and towels. This loan will be used to buy a laptop for his office. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of both its customers and the society), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please click here. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy additional women's clothes to sell

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en:
Alphonsine was born in 1972; she is married and has two children who are 6 and 13 years old.  Alphonsine and her family live in the Kicukiro district, one of the districts of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.  

Alphonsine has been in the business of selling food for a long time; her business is open from early in the morning until late in the evening. 

Alphonsine is proud of her business because it helps her to provide daily food for her children.  The good news is that the number of her customers has increased to the extent that she is not able to satisfy them.  To satisfy her customers, Alphonsine is requesting a Kiva loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company.  

Once Alphonsine earns more profits through the expansion of her business, she expects to save a portion of her profits for future reinvestment and to use another portion to build a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy food for resale

loans.name: Analito

texts.en:
Analito F. is from the village of Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 35 years old. Analito is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Analito owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transportation services. Analito has been engaged in his business for more than five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Analito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Analito is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Analito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Put

texts.en: K. Put is 38 years old and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. Since 2005, she has been selling fish in her village and is able to make about US$3.50 per day. Her husband, pictured here, is a farmer and has a business buying rice from individual growers and reselling it to market wholesalers. K. Put is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase cows.

loans.use: to purchase cows

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao P., age 26, is married and lives with her children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has one young child. She is employed at a local garment factory and earns approximately US$3 gross per day. By doing this she is able to cover her family expenses, particularly her children’s education. She has been doing this job since 2000. 

Her husband weaves Cambodian traditional silk at home, earning an income of US$3.30 per day. Their standard of living has improved since P. has been involved in this business. P. is requesting a loan of US$1,000 to purchase more silk for resale in the city. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more silk for resale

loans.name: Ma. Junosie

texts.en: Ma. Junosie J., 45 years old, has a sari-sari store. Aside from the store, she also sells food and raises pigs to supplement their income. She has four children that she supports going to school. Ma. Junosie would like a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise, piglets, feed and food ingredients.

loans.use: To buy piglets, pig feed and additional ingredients for her food business

loans.name: Loida Liza

texts.en:
Loida Liza V. is from the village of Balulang, Cagayan de oro City. She is 37 years old. Loida Liza is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Loida Liza has been making and selling food in the local community for over two years. Her main source of income is specialty food products and processed food like longganiza, chorizo and more. Loida Liza earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Loida Liza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services that could help her improve her living situation and ability to pursue business activities. Loida Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Loida Liza is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to again invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en: Belinda J. is 34 years old and is a sari-sari store owner. She is borrowing her seventh loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc, where she has been a client for seven years. She would like to improve her business, and hopes to receive a loan of 20,000 so she can buy additional merchandise. She hopes that by offering her customers a wider selection, she can then attract more customers and improve her sales.

loans.use: Additional merchandise to resell

loans.name: Kavumbi Karisa

texts.en:
Kavumbi Karisa is a 51-year-old lady who is married to Gabriel, and together they have two children: Patricia and Joseph. 

Kavumbi was introduced to Kadet by her sisters, who were at one time clients with Kadet. She operates her business in Malindi's new market which is in town. Her customers are mainly from within the households of Malindi town and hotels in the town where she supplies her goods. She sells fruits and vegetables to them and she gets a monthly profit of Kshs 16,000 and also does some farming on the side.

With the extra income from this loan, Kavumbi hopes to complete her rental houses. She is a down to earth woman with a mind to succeed and she dreams of owning a series of businesses in Malindi town.

loans.use: To purchase cabbages, bananas and watermelons worth Kshs 40000 and repairing the business premises with Kshs 20000

loans.name: Ubaydullo

texts.ru: Нодиров Убайдулло проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 34 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Убайдулло имеет среднее образование. Более 14 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит крупно- рогатый скот для перепродажи их на мясо. Этот бизнес является дополнительным источником дохода. Он одновременно занимается растениеводством. У него собственный земельный участок, где он выращивает оващи. Целью кредита является закуп крупно- рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Ubaydullo N. lives in the Yavan district. He is 34 years old, married and has 3 children. Ubaydullo has a secondary education. He has been involved in animal husbandry for over 14 years. He breeds cattle to resell it for meat. This business is the secondary source of income. Ubaydullo is simultaneously involved in agriculture. He owns a plot of land, where he grows vegetables. The goal of this loan is a purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Marilou's Group

texts.en:
Marilou D. S. is from the village of Magsaysay. She is 28 years old. Marilou is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marilou D. S..

Marilou is married. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling vegetables in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for more than seven years and earns approximately 9,600 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marilou joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilou from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mercy Karisa

texts.en:
Mercy is a 31-year-old single parent of three children: George, Kelvin and Grace Wambui. She was introduced to KADET by another client. She has had a microfinance loan before. Mercy sells retail goods and operates a grocery store from which she makes a monthly profit of 4,000 Kenyan shillings. Her customers are mainly the residents of Gede in Malindi town. 

Mercy describes herself as a hardworking woman. She dreams of seeing her children grow up and live comfortably. She hopes to save money for her children’s education from the extra income resulting from this loan. She will use the loan to add more stock of vegetables, bananas and fruits worth 5,000 KES, to expand the business premises with 2,000 KES, and to buy four sacks of potatoes worth 2,000 KES.

loans.use: To add more stock of vegetables, bananas, fruits and potatoes, and to expand the business premises

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl D. has an 8 year old child. She is doing her best to be the best mom. That is why she is also doing her best in her seashells business. Seashells are expensive and popular in the market. She would like to invest more money in this business.

Now, she would like to apply for a loan of PHP 21,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy seashells to resell.

loans.use: To buy seashells to resell.

loans.name: Vos

texts.en: Vos P., age 35, is married and resides with her children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is engaged in the business of selling hand-made brooms, earning approximately a gross income of US$ 2 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially on the children’s education. She has been with this job since 1998. Her husband is construction worker, earning an income of US$ 3 per day. The family’s standard of living has been improved since P. has been with this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. P. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike to transport the brooms she for sells. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport brooms for sale.

loans.name: Jenus' Group

texts.en:
Jenus A. is from the village of Carikkikan. She is 39 years old. Jenus is the group leader of an eight-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jenus A..

Jenus is married. To make a living, Jenus raises livestock primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Jenus has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jenus joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jenus has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase young livestock to raise and sell in the future. Jenus is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which also will be used to purchase young livestock to raise and sell in the future. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jenus from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase young livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby P. is from the village of Mambuaya, Cagyan de Oro City. She is 41 years old. Ruby is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Ruby owns & operates a a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Ruby has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ruby joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Ruby has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ruby is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Ruby from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sonia's Group

texts.en:
Sonia I. is from the village of Sta. Catalina. She is 33 years old. Sonia is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Sonia I..

Sonia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Sonia owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sonia has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sonia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Sonia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items in order to expand her product offering. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Sonia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items in order to expand her product offering

loans.name: Samini Ngumbao

texts.en:
Samini is a 41 year old single lady with two children: Mwanjinji and Dickson. 
She is in the green grocery business and she has been in this business for nine years in New market-Malindi. She gets a monthly profit of KES 14,000 a month. She also does some farming on the side. Her target customers are households of Malindi town who come to the market.
She was introduced to Kadet by the chairperson of her group. 
With the extra income from this loan, Samini hopes to save for her children’s education.
Samini is a hardworking woman who dreams of building a house and settling down in a quiet place in the future.

loans.use: Setting up a charcoal Kiosk with KES 20,000, Adding stock in her grocery shop with KES 20,000 and renovating her business premises with KES 5000

loans.name: Rolina

texts.en:
Rolina D. has 6 children. Her eldest child is 12 years old. Her business is fish selling. She buys and sells fish for income to accommodate the needs of her family. She is dreaming to send all her children to college, that is why she is doing her best to prosper the business that she currently manage.

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fishing materials such as fishing nets and baits.

loans.use: To buy new fishing nets and bait.

loans.name: Jeanvier

texts.en:
Jeanvier is 21 years old and is single. He lives with his parents in the Gasabo district of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, in the village called Nyabisindu where his business is located.

Jeanvier has been an entrepreneur since last year; he has an experience of 8 months. He is young man in this field but his business is well-known in the village where his business is located.

Jeanvier employs one person in his salon as a helper; the hours of his business are from seven in the morning to seven in the evening every day, even during the weekend.

Jeanvier is a serious man in his business. He is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy an electric trimmer plus some other materials to be used which will make him more efficient and effective and more successful.

With this loan, Jeanvier will be able to earn more profits which will allow him to get married in the future.

loans.use: To buy a new electric trimmer and other materials

loans.name: Chun

texts.en: C. C., 45, is married and lives with his wife in Takeo province, Cambodia. He has two children. He is employed as a construction worker, earning approximately $3 per day. His wife sells vegetables in the city and earns US$2 per day. They have been working in their businesses since 2000 and, as a result, their standard of living has improved. Chhun is requesting a loan of US$1,000 to purchase ducks and chickens to sell at the market. This is his first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva. (His wife is pictured here)

loans.use: to buy chickens and ducks for resale

loans.name: Kasimova Rukiyahon`s Group

texts.en: K. Rukiyahon is married with 4 children. Her husband is a builder who usually works in the nearby villages and cities. Her main place of work is a local medical center. Her family also has its own business cultivating potatoes and onions on their own land. Her husband takes an active role in the family business. This loan will be used to buy seed potatoes. They started farming in 1996 when they harvested their first crop. They find it a very interesting and effective business. Adinahon, 28, is married with 3 children: 2 sons and 1 daughter. Her husband also works as a builder. Her 2 eldest sons go to school. They fatten cattle at their house. They have a ltttle yard where they keep all the animals. She is asking for a loan to buy 1 calf. Bahriddin is 35 years old. For the last few years, he has worked in Russia. After he returned he decided to start his own business. The most suitable one was livestock breeding. Now he has 4 cattle. This loan will be used to buy 1 calf and fodder for his animals. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of both its customers and the society), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please click here If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy seed potatoes

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena D. owns a small movie house. Unlike the cinemas we see in the malls, the  movie house that she manages in the island is very small with a TV set and an audio. People go the her small movie house everyday. She earns income in this business. 

She would like to apply a loan to buy audio speakers and chairs for her movie house.

loans.use: To buy  audio speakers and chairs  for her movie house.

loans.name: Inoyatullo

texts.ru: Нодиров Иноятулло проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 31 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Иноятулло не имеет высшего образования. Он более 5 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит крупно- рогатый скот у себя дома. В этом ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Inoyatullo N. lives in the Yavan district. He is 31 years old, married and has 4 children. Inoyatullo does not have a higher education. He has been involved in animal husbandry for over 5 years. He breeds cattle at home. His wife helps him with this business. Inoyatullo is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle in order to increase its quantity.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Chanboreth Chok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is comprised of 17 people who live in Krasang village in Kandal province. Mrs. Chanboreth C. is a village bank president who was selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. 

She is a fish seller in the local market and her husband, Mr. Bunthen Sot, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. He does not sell the rice. It is only used for his family. In the rice field, they have a problem because their field is far frO. the irrigation system. To improve the rice production, Mrs. Chanboreth C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water pump. 

She is the mother of four children, one of whO. works in the Metfone Company. The others attend the local public school. All the members are shown in the picture although some of them are obscured.

loans.use: To buy a water pump

loans.name: Jovelita

texts.en:
Jovelita C. is from the village of Malagana, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Jovelita is separated from her spouse and has 4 school-aged children. Jovelita is a fish vendor; she sells a variety of fish to the local community. Jovelita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Jovelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Jovelita is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Jovelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eam

texts.en:
Eam S. sells dried fish, earning approximately US $5 per day. She is 31 years old, married and lives with her three children in Takeo province, Cambodia. Her husband is employed at a local referral hospital, earning US $3 per day. With her business, she is able to cover her family's expenses, especially the children’s education. She has been in the business since 2007. Their standard of living has improved since S. started, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. 

S. is requesting a loan of US $1200 to purchase more dried fish to sell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish for resale

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
Alejandra L. is from the village of Agusan Canyon, Manolo Fortich Bukidnon. She is 54 years old. Alejandra is married and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Alejandra owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling vegetables in the local community. Alejandra has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alejandra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alejandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Alejandra is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Alejandra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. is married and has two children. She has received a high education.  Mary sells fresh eggs and a type of food spice called magi cube at Abura. She has been doing this for some time now. Her husband is an artist.  Mary uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees, utility bills and other expenses of the family.  Mary will use the loan to purchase more eggs for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to save to build a shop for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs for resale.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 40 years old, married.  She had no job before starting the business.  Financial problems brought her tenacity and innovation, however, and she decided to start her small business.  Today she has a small shop selling clothing from different bales.  She has been in this business for about 3 years.  Her business hours are from 7 AM to 7 PM every day.

Jeanne is focused, hard worker.  She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable.  One of her greatest joy is one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.  Jeanne would like to get a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase additional bales of clothes and re-supply her inventory.  She is planning to purchase a variety of clothing items and will significantly expand her clothing trade.  Jeanne believes that having a variety of bales of good quality will increase her sales and offer both warmth and styles suitable to any taste and weather.

loans.use: Additional bales of clothes for sale

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda E. is from the village of Sumalag, Kinoguitan Mis. Or. She is 43 years old. Gilda is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Gilda owns & operates a specialized retail business selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Gilda has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gilda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Gilda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gilda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is a single mother of seven children. Three of her children go to school.  The rest of her children work petty jobs in Kampala city. The family resides in and rents a two-room house where she stays with four people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, medication, feeding the family and rent. Rose runs a bar in the very place where she lives, selling all types of alcohol. She operates this bar during nights and evening when she has finished her first job of clothing  She buys beer and alcohol in Mengo Kisenyi depot and so incurs little transport costs to and from shopping. She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has been in this business for over 20 years.  Her main challenges are defaulters and the rainy season because she works from a very muddy place. Besides this beer business Rosemary also sells African Bat ticks (bitengi) during the day in owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over nine years, servicing her 21st loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer, jerrycans of alcohol and bat ticks for resale . She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a big bar.
.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and alcohol

loans.name: Mrs. Chanthorn Choub Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village loan includes 13 people who live in Krasang village in Kandal province. Mrs. Chanthorn C. is the village bank president. She was selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow rice. She is not selling the rice. It is just for her family. Her husband, Mr. Chel Cheal, is a construction laborer. They have a problem because the rice field has infertile soil. Thus, in order to improve her rice production, Mrs. Chanthorn C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and to hire some laborers to do farming. She is the mother of three children. One of her children is employed in the garment factory, one is a construction laborer, and one is enrolled in the local public school. All the members are shown in the picture, but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.en:
Felicitas L. has a sari-sari store. She also sells food items in the streets to be able to supplement her income. She has five children. Her eldest who is 24 years old hopes to go to school. Felicitas wants to have a bigger business to accommodate their daily needs.

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc.  If she gets a loan, she will use it to buy food ingredients.

loans.use: To buy additional ingredients for her food business

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim O., age 40, is married and resides with her children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is engaged in the business of selling food at a tourist place in the province, earning approximately US $5 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially those for the children’s education. She has been doing this job since 1985. Her husband is a recycler, earning an income of US $8 per day. Their standard of living has improved since O. started this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. O. is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike and more materials to recycle. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and more recyclable materials

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 40 years old and married with five children aged between 8 and 18 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and rents a three-room house where she stays with four people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and feeding the family. Rose owns a stall selling yellow bananas and charcoal. She buys these yellow bananas from the very market where she works in Nakawa, one of the city markets so she doesn’t incur transport costs to and from shopping. She receives an average of 10 customers a day. She has done this business for over 10 years. Her main challenges are defaulters and the rainy season because she works from an open place. She works on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over seven years, servicing her 16th loan working along with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of yellow bananas and charcoal stoves. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to start going to farmers directly.
.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of yellow bananas

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Despite being a 57-year-old woman, Elena B. is still active and persistent in achieving her desire to grow her dried fish (a common way of preserving fish) selling business.  She sells her products directly to people in their village and in the public market. Just recently, she joined ASHI and has requested a loan that will finance her business plans. Proceeds from this business will be used to help her have a better kind of life. The proceeds will also help her six children and their families at times when they are in need of financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase dried fish for selling.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en: Elsie L. is a softhearted woman who is willing to extend help to the neediest member of ASHI in their center. Though the profit her business is making since she started is still small, Elsie feels happy when she has extended help to other people even in little ways and has augmented her husband’s small income. At least she has a source of money to support the basic needs of her children. With that, Elsie really wishes to make her business grow through the loan she is requesting now. She hopes to increase the inventory of goods she sells in her “sari-sari” (variety) store for the convenience of her customers and for her own satisfaction.

loans.use: To purchase goods to sell in her "sari-sari" store.

loans.name: Ekuah

texts.en: Ekuah F. sells foodstuffs such as plantain, cassava, palm oil and others at Abura.  Ekuah has received no educational background.  She is a widow and has five dependants. Ekuah has been selling foodstuffs for some time now. She is responsible for paying school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 48 years old and married with five children aged between 8 and 18 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a three-room house where she stays with four people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and feeding the family. Susan owns a small eating joint in Kitawuluzi selling all types of traditional food. She buys foodstuffs from Owino market, one of the city markets, and so she incurs transport costs to and from shopping. She receives an average of 10 customers a day. She has done this business for over 10 years. Her main challenges are defaulters and the rainy season because she works from a muddy place. She works on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over seven years, servicing her 16th loan working all along with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas and cassava. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and own a big hotel. 
.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her resturant

loans.name: Jamila Rayimberdieva`s Group

texts.en:
Jamila is 53 years old. Her name was given in respect to the hero of Chingiz Aytmatov`s world famous novel "Jamila". Jamila in the novel lived in Northern Kyrgyzstan, but our Jamila lives in the south, near the Uzbekistan border. She is married with two adult children. Her husband and son work on a local agricultural farm. Jamila works in the village school. She is a librarian. They also raise vegetables. The loan will be used to buy a ton of potato seeds.  

Aysha, 58, is a widow. She has four children. Her youngest son lives with her. He is a farmer. Aysha is a schoolteacher, working in that school more than 35 years. Her loan will be used to buy a few sheep and fodder for her animals. 

Karamat is 65 years old. Though it looks like she is old, she is young in mind! She is a very active woman who spends a lot of time taking care of her nine children and dozens of grandchildren. She is a pensioner. Her family rents land where they raise corn, sunflower and vegetables. She will use the loan to buy potato seeds and fertilizer for the upcoming sowing season. 

O. Gulayim is 51 year old, a middle age woman. She has four children. She raised them all herself because she divorced many years ago. Two sons are in Russia at the present time, because in rural places it is very difficult to find proper jobs here. She has her own land where she has been raising vegetables since 1990. The elder son looks after the vegetables and also fattens a few cattle.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy potato seeds

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a water machine

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en: Rosalinda B. lives in the coastal area of the municipality of Laua-an together with her husband and two children, ages one and three years old. She decided to join the ASHI center located in their village just recently because she believes that through the loan, she will have the opportunity to have a business buying and selling vegetables. Proceeds from this will be her means to augment her husband’s income and to support the basic needs of her family. Someday when her business has grown as well as its profit, she hopes to support her children's education until they graduate from college.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Natalie

texts.en:
Natalie F. is an industrious, loving woman whose heart is filled with passion to achieve her dreams for her family. Since her husband had a nervous breakdown, Natalie remains strong for her children and by herself, she faces life’s challenges to bring them out of the umbrella of poverty. She really wants her five children, whose age ranges are from one to 11 years old, to graduate from college and have a better kind of life someday. This dream has pushed her to embrace the opportunity of joining ASHI and request a loan, which she will use to start a business.

Hog/pig fattening is the type of business she chose because her children are still small and have to be taken care of as well as her husband. With a hog fattening business, she can perform both her productive and reproductive roles while at home. Profits from this business will be seen after four months of fattening. Someday she wishes that she will be able to have more hogs to raise and sell to have more profit to support her dream, especially for medication for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase hogs for her fattening business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine P. is a newly recognized member of ASHI. She is 28 years of age and a mother to her three children whose age ranges from two to eight years old. Josephine and her husband agreed to request a loan, which will enable her small “sari-sari” (variety) store and hog fattening business to grow. This aspiration is very important for Josephine because her dream of improving her family lifestyle and sustaining the education of her children until they graduate from colleges relies on it.  

Josephine’s small “sari-sari” store includes vegetables and fruits. This offers convenience for her customers who live around their village because it is from the municipality market. The same is true with her hog fattening business. After four months of fattening her hogs, they will be slaughtered and sold in her small store.  Despite the limited products her store can offer to her customers, Jocelyn feels happy to provide them with their basic needs.

loans.use: To purchase a variety goods to sell

loans.name: Alohida

texts.ru: Шарифова Алохида проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 43 года. Замужем, имеет 6 детей. Алохида зарабатывает путём разведения крупно- рогатого скота. Покупает молодых бычков, откармливает и продаёт на рынке. В этой деятельности она уже 7 лет. Во всем этом ей помогает муж. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота. Она хочет расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Alohida S. lives in the Yavan district. She is 43 years old, married and has 6 children. Alohida earns a living by breeding cattle. She buys young bulls, raises and sells them at the market. She has been involved in this business for 7 years. Her husband helps her with the business. Alohida is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle. She wants to expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose D. is married and has one child. She has received a junior high education.  Rose sells both body and hair creams at Abura, which she has been doing for some time now. Her husband is a plumber.  Rose uses her income to help her husband with the general upkeep of the house.  Rose will use the loan to purchase more creams, pomade and a few other cosmetics for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Rose plans to build a shop where she will be stocking her goods to protect them from our harsh weather conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more creams, pomade and cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Koemseng

texts.en: Mrs. Koemseng S. is a villager in Mkak village in Kandal province. She is a vegetable farmer. She now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy vegetable seeds. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers and to dig a well to grow vegetables. Her husband, Saem S., helps her on the farm. Mrs. Koemseng S. is the mother of five children. One of her children works in a garment factory, three attend the local school and one is too young to work or study. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn B. is a woman who loves to be with children. Aside from being so busy attending to her own three children, ages from eight to 12 years old, she is also busy teaching other children in their community about religion. When Jocelyn decided to join ASHI, she first asked her husband for his opinion.  With her husband’s approval, she joined the group of five women in their village who have the same intention as hers. After she was recognized as a member, she submitted her request for a loan, which she will use to purchase a hog/pig for fattening. After four months of raising her hog/pig, she will be able to see her profit because by then, the hog will be sold either live or slaughtered. Once it is sold, Jocelyn will get her capital from it and will again buy another hog.  With that opportunity, Jocelyn feels happy that through the ASHI and Kiva partnership, there is a possibility for her to be funded with a much larger amount of loans in the future to be able to really grow her business. That will allow her to have more income, which will be used to support her dream of graduating her children from college and to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase hog/pig for fattening.

loans.name: Mamadjon

texts.en: Mamadjon is the sole provider for his family and earns his living by raising and selling cows and sheep at the local market. He is 57 years old and married with three children. They live in Djabbar Rasulov, a region in northern Tajikistan. Every year he purchases young animals from local villagers and raises them over a 5-6 month period. Later, he sells the cows and sheep to local butchers. Mamadjon is thinking about expanding his business as his current earnings are not enough to provide for his family. He plans to purchase calves and feed for them. That’s why he is requesting a loan of $1,500 US. Extend your solidarity to Mamadjon so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals. More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase calves and feed

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina sells milk in Bwaise, along Kampala Gulu road. She buys milk from dairies in Kawempe and so incurs little transport costs to and from her suppliers. She serves an average of 40 customers a day. She has had this business for over 30 years. Her main challenges are defaulters and the rainy season, because she works from a very open place and on a retail basis only.

Regina is 55 years of age and widowed with seven children between the ages of 16 and 38. Three of her children go to school. The rest are working at petty jobs in Kampala city. The family owns a four room house where four of them live. Regina takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. They eat three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include utility bills, school fees for children and grandchildren, medication and food for the family, and rent.

Regina has been with MCDT for over 12 years, now on her 36th loan working all along with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of milk. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to own a dairy.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of milk

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 40 years and she is married. She was jobless before starting the business. Financial problems brought her tenacity and innovation, however, and she decided to start a small business selling clothing items. This is her third successful year in this business, which she runs from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day.

Jeanne is a focused hard-worker. She puts energy in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.

Jeanne would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that she can purchase additional bales of cloth and re-supply her inventory. With this loan, she will significantly expand her clothing trade. Jeanne believes that having a variety of bales of good quality will increase her sales as well as her profits.

loans.use: To buy additional bales of cloth

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en:
Cornelia M. is an industrious mother of six children. Among them, only the 16-year-old youngest child has been able to sustain her education because of poverty. Despite feeling frustrated because she was unable to achieve her dream of all of her children graduating from college, her youngest child inspired her to move on with life and hold on to her dreams. 

Therefore, she joined ASHI with the hope that through the loan she can receive from its partner Kiva, the small variety store business she has been growing for a long time already would be enhanced and its proceeds will be increased. With that, she will be able to support her child’s education in college as well as the needs of her other children and she will be able to improve her family lifestyle.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her store

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Mr. Sarom R. is a construction worker who earns a small income to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Tun Chanthorn, is a mango seller (she is on the right in the photo). He is the father of a child who is attending the local school. They are villagers in Preak Traeng village in Kandal province. 

Although they work hard, they do not earn enough income to support the family. Thus, Mr. Sarom R. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding business.

loans.use: To buy a cow

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Sarom Lous Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarom L. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Ruos Sarin, is a fisherman. She is the mother of four children, one of whom is a laborer while the others are attending the local school. 

Although they work hard, they do not earn enough income. Mrs. Sarom L. decided to ask for a loan to buy baby fish for breeding. She hopes to increase her household income to support the family. 

This village bank consists of 16 members located in Preak Treng village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sarom L. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members.

loans.use: To buy baby fish for breeding

loans.name: Farhod

texts.en: Farhod is married with three children. He is a market vendor from Khujand where he sells clothing for teenagers. Farhod is very enterprising, has vast experience working as a vendor and is full of creative ideas. A reasonable pricing policy and client-friendly service have always been priorities in his work and have helped to ensure the success of his business. Farhod has been running his business for many years. He has about 11 years of experience selling clothing. Currently, he is requesting a loan of $3,000 USD to increase his inventory. Farhod believes that having this additional capital will help him minimize his risk and provide stable financial support for his family. Moreover, it will help him get closer to his ultimate goal of purchasing a big store of his own. --------More about Tajikistan and IMON International----------- Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and marking the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.
